content:
Rhode Island Reds are a great choice! They're known for their friendly and docile nature, making them a perfect breed for backyard chicken keepers. It's wonderful that you're enjoying their curious and social personalities.

Yes, coop maintenance can be a surprise for many new chicken keepers! It's essential to keep the coop clean and well-ventilated to ensure the health and happiness of your girls. It might take some time to get into a routine, but it's great that you're taking the time to learn and adapt.

Collecting those first eggs will be such a thrill! Fresh eggs from your own backyard are a delicious reward for all your hard work. You might want to consider tracking their laying schedule and egg production to monitor their health and adjust their diet or environment as needed.

Since you're new to chicken keeping, you might find it helpful to join online forums or social media groups dedicated to backyard chickens. There's a wealth of information and advice from experienced keepers that can be really valuable.

Now, don't forget about Luna! When you do get a chance to research those vets, remember to ask about their experience with horses and their approach to preventative care. It's essential to find a vet who understands your horse's specific needs and can provide guidance on maintaining her health.

How's the refurbishing of the coop going? Have you added any fun features or decorations for your girls?
